instruction: What kinds of spectrum was used to present the development of an on-line surface defect system for jujubes?
Output: The related study used visible spectrum to present the development of an on-line surface defect system for jujubes.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to classify surface defects of jujubes?
Output: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Savitsky-Golay Filter were used for spectral feature processing in order to classify surface defects of jujubes.

instruction: What metric was chosen to present the development of an on-line surface defect system for jujubes, and how far can this metric go?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the classification accuracies of the SVM and ANN models for jujube skin defects is the percentage accuracy. The paper states that the classification accuracies of the SVM and ANN models, using the full wavelength range, are 96.3% and 96.5% respectively.

instruction: How were the machine learning models used in the development of the on-line surface defect system using hyperspectral images for jujubes?
Output:
In the development of the on-line surface defect system using hyperspectral images for jujubes, two machine learning models were used: Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Artificial Neural Networks (ANN). These models were employed to classify the surface defects of jujubes based on the hyperspectral images.

The classification accuracies of the SVM and ANN models, using the full wavelength range of 468-950 nm, were found to be 96.3% and 96.5% respectively. However, the processing time for one jujube face was 320 seconds for the SVM model and 25 seconds for the ANN model.

To reduce the computation time of the online classification tasks, spectral bands were selected from a wavelength range of 468-760 nm. This selection was done either by using equal band intervals or by applying the Principal Component Analysis (PCA) method.

Experimental results showed that using 14 bands (469, 491, 513, 535, 558, 580, 602, 624, 646, 668, 691, 713, 735, and 757 nm) selected by equal wavelength intervals, the accuracy of the SVM model was 94.4% and the accuracy of the ANN model was 95%.

instruction: Can the classification accuracies of the ANN and SVM models for jujube skin defects using the full wavelength range be considered superior to traditional methods in surface defect detection of other fruits?
Output: Yes, the classification accuracies of the ANN and SVM models for jujube skin defects using the full wavelength range (96.5% and 96.3% respectively) can be considered superior to traditional methods in surface defect detection of other fruits.
